oai_dc:dc.dc:title: DEEP LEARNING TO PREDICT TSUNAMI HEIGHT AT THE SHORELINE USING OCEAN BOTTOM PRESSURE DATA
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Renteria, Willington
Lynett, Patrick
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Real-time tsunami prediction is a required component of a tsunami warning system. Several advances have been made to improve prediction in the tsunami warning process, including precomputed databases and the assimilation of deep-ocean observations (DART buoys) into numerical modeling (Bernard and Titov, 2015). These improvements aim to accurately and quickly predict the time and height of the tsunami wave impact. Here, two deep learning models (DLM) are developed to predict the maximum tsunami height at a local/long shoreline from four time series observations of ocean bottom pressure data.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Coastal Engineering Proceedings; No. 37 (2022): Proceedings of 37th Conference on Coastal Engineering, Sydney, Australia, 2022; management.98
